column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0002] The invention relates to a method and reactor for applying a coating to a fiber by chemical vapor deposition (CVD).
#Text=Also, the invention relates to an article comprising a multiplicity of fiber tows.
#Text=[0003] Fiber reinforced ceramic matrix composites (CMCs) are formed of continuous uniaxial or woven fibers of ceramic material embedded in a ceramic matrix.
#Text=These materials are designed to have a relatively weak fiber-matrix bond strength compared to the matrix strength so as to increase overall composite strength and toughness.
#Text=When the CMC is loaded above a stress that initiates cracks in the matrix, the fibers debond from the matrix allowing fiber/matrix sliding without fiber fracture.
#Text=The fibers can then bridge a matrix crack and transfer load to the surrounding matrix by transferring tensile stresses to frictional interfacial shear forces.
#Text=The fiber reinforced CMCs have great potential for use in aircraft and gas turbine engines due to their excellent properties at high temperatures.
#Text=[0004] The CMCs can be manufactured by filament winding.

#Text=In this process, fibers, usually in the form of long fiber tows, are saturated with a slurry of matrix powder in suitable solvents and binders and are then wound onto a mandrel to form cylinders or sheets of matrix containing aligned fibers.
#Text=The impregnated shapes made therefrom are at this stage of the process commonly termed "prepregs."
#Text=A prepreg can be reshaped as desired and ultimately formed into a preform for a composite article.
#Text=The preform is subjected to a burn-out step to remove organic or other fugitive coating components.
#Text=The preform is finally consolidated into a dense composite material by reaction with molten silicon at high temperature.

#Text=[0005] The fibers are coated for several purposes such as to protect them during composite processing, to modify fiber-matrix interface strength and to promote or prevent mechanical and/or chemical bonding of the fiber and matrix.
#Text=A number of different techniques have been developed for applying fiber coatings, such as slurry-dipping, sol-gel, sputtering and chemical vapor deposition (CVD).
#Text=Of these, CVD has been most successful in producing impervious coatings of uniform thickness and controlled composition.
#Text=In a typical CVD process, fibers and reactants are heated to some elevated temperature where coating precursors decompose and deposit as a coating.
#Text=CVD coatings can be applied either in a batch or continuous mode.
#Text=In a batch mode, a length of fiber is introduced into a reactor and kept stationary throughout the coating process while reactants are passed through the reactor.
#Text=In a continuous process, fibers and coating precursors are continuously passed through a reactor.
#Text=Continuous fiber coating processes are preferred for composites processed by filament winding.
#Text=[0006] One common continuous fiber coating process involves running a single tow or fiber into the reactor at a time.
#Text=The coating is conducted at low pressure to insure uniform coating.
#Text=The tow or fiber is transported through the reactor only at a slow speed.
#Text=Although current processes provide useful results, there remains a need for further improvements to CVD processes for uniformly coating fiber tows with higher productivity.
